bibl.title: Despatch from Charles P. Clark to Abraham Lincoln
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
To His Excellency
Abraham Lincoln,
President of the United States.
Please read the annexed copies of letters addressed to the late Prest. of the United States, no reply to which has ever been received.

And if your many pressing duties will allow you to consider the subject at this time, I beg you to examine the Statutes therein referred to, as well as the precedents, a list of some of which, is appended.

I have requested the United States Commercial Agent at Monrovia to communicate the facts in the case, in official despatches, and doubt not that you will find at the State Department such statements as will convince you of the propriety of affording immediate
relief to those of us who for so long have been endeavoring to build up a legitimate trade with the Coast of Africa, as we have reason to fear that discriminating duties will soon be levied upon our vessels, unless justice is done to Liberian interests in the United States.

I am, Sir,
Yours very resp'y
Charles P. Clark

To
James Buchanan,
President of the United States.
The writer begs to call your attention to his letter of 11 June, of which copy is enclosed.
The matter is one of interest to me and an early answer is solicited.

Very respectfully,
Yours
(signed) Chas. P. Clark
